rPMTUx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Aquatic species, only terrestrial systems selected apply to nesting habitat.  ****Width of stream would be a good layer for predicting this species occurrence in rivers and streams (if categorized would include in medium and large streams/rivers). Flow Accumulation may be a good predictor for this species since it needs wider, moving rivers and streams.  Probably could set minimum threshold for accumulation, can't find any literature to support and type of slope, threshold etc., but in CP could probably use min of 5-10.  Amy Silvano 7jul05

Changed interior flowing buffer from 0m to 60m. MJR 30 January 2008.

habitat_description:
The distribution of this map turtle is restricted to the Pascagoula River system across Mississippi (Ennen et al. 2010; Lovich and McCoy 1992; Lovich et al. 2009). In more detail, populations are established in the Pascagoula, Leaf, Chickasawhay, Chunky, and lower Escatawpa rivers, and Bogue Homa, Red, Bouie, Bucatunna, Long, Gaines, Oakohay, Okatibbee, Okatoma, Red, Souinlovey, Tallahala, and Tallahoma creeks (Lovich et al. 2009; Selman and Qualls 2009). These habitats are described as big and medium sized rivers characterized by low gradient currents.

This species is known to burrow in or using soil, decaying logs, and leaf litter. It is common to find these turtles in rivers that possess an abundance of mollusks, deep pools, sandy banks, and suitable basking objects. This species also is found in shallow water and even into sandy beaches at night. Cover is usually provided by floating, aquatic vegetation (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Lovich and McCoy 1992).


Map turtles live strictly in riverine-riparian systems and associated floodplain sloughs, lakes, and ponds. They nest on sandy banks or sand bars, but sometimes can be found up to about 100 m from water bodies.
